intro: Rubia occidens, commonly known as the western madder, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, white or pinkish flowers. The plant produces red to orange roots that have been historically used for dyeing textiles. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often branched and somewhat woody. Rubia occidens thrives in sunny, well-drained soils and is often found in dry grasslands and rocky areas.
